Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Inadmissibility based on lack of durable solution prospects
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants fled Sierra Leone's civil war and applied for permanent residence but were found inadmissible due to involvement with the Civil Defense Unit
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Officer did not assess compelling reasons exception under section 108(4)
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Finding of no reasonable prospect of durable solutions elsewhere
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No explicit finding of past persecution
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Applications dismissed except for complicity determination
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed applications except complicity finding quashed
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Officer Blouin's decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 108(4) exception for compelling reasons in cases of past persecution
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Section 108(4) not triggered due to absence of finding of past persecution

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged complicity in crimes against humanity during Sierra Leone civil war
Crimes.Outcome: Complicity determination quashed, application dismissed on other grounds
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Involvement with Civil Defense Unit during conflict
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, international human rights law
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Complicity finding set aside, application dismissed
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Crimes.Credibility: Persecution claims not meeting 'appalling' or 'atrocious' threshold

Violation_Type: Failure to rebut presumption of state protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Subsection 108(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Ms. Polak and Mr. Musialek claimed refugee status due to fear of persecution by Ms. Polak's father in Poland
Procedural_Issue: Failure to seek state protection in Poland
Testimonial inconsistencies
Evidence_Used: Board findings on existence of state protection mechanisms in Poland
Evidence of delays in legal proceedings
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide compelling reasons for refusal of state protection
Inconsistencies in testimony
Credibility_Assessment: The Board found Ms. Polak failed to seek state protection; credibility affected by inconsistencies
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim dismissed
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of Refugee Protection Division decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Compelling reasons for refusing state protection
Decision_Rationale: Poland has adequate mechanisms to address domestic violence; claimants did not prove lack of effective state protection

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee status denial
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in finding that the 'compelling reasons' exception is not applicable
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 108(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Suleiman's persecution was found credible
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimony, psychological impact, past persecution evidence
Crimes.Application_Error: Incorrectly required persecution to be 'atrocious' or 'appalling'
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Misapplication of the threshold for 'compelling reasons'
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Compelling reasons arising from past persecution

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Repeated beatings due to political opinion
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Targeted violence based on political affiliation
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, medical records, psychological evaluation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Persecution acknowledged as credible by the Board
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 108(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Violation_Type: Abuse of power by state authorities
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 108(4), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants subjected to physical abuse and harassment due to political opinion
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Lawfully present in Canada during claim process
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Error in applying legal standard for 'compelling reasons'
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Testimony, psychological reports, country condition reports
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible and consistent accounts
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Board applied too high a threshold ('atrocious', 'appalling')

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International refugee law, Canadian immigration law
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Board denied claim based on changed country conditions
Crimes.Risk_Factor: History of detention, beatings, business disruption

Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Suleiman detained multiple times due to political activities
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible and corroborated

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether denial constitutes part of compelling reasons for protection
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate compelling reasons
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Compelling reasons may arise from cumulative persecution
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Denial of schooling, beatings, business confiscation
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, country reports, psychological evaluations

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether property seizure contributes to 'compelling reasons'
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Claim denied due to perceived lack of severity
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Cumulative harm may constitute compelling reasons
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, financial records

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Misapplication of the 'compelling reasons' exception
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants' claims found credible
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimony, psychological reports, country condition data
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Past persecution due to political opinion
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Existence of compelling reasons from past persecution

Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee definition under IRPA
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) - Refugee Status Provisions
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed past persecution in Mauritania based on ethnicity and imputed political opinion; Board found discrimination but not persecution; country conditions have changed, reducing future risk
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenging the Refugee Protection Division's rejection of refugee claim
Evidence_Used: Board's assessment of country conditions in Mauritania, applicants' testimony, evidence of ethnic discrimination
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence to establish persecution as opposed to discrimination
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus was on legal interpretation and reasonableness of decision
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected by the Board
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no question certified
Relief_Sought: Recognition as Convention refugees or persons in need of protection
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Fear of persecution on enumerated grounds under IRPA; changed country conditions
Decision_Rationale: The Board reasonably concluded that while there was evidence of discrimination, it did not amount to persecution; changed circumstances in Mauritania mitigate future risk; no compelling reasons to override country condition changes
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD erred in dismissing the applicants' refugee claims due to inadequate evidence of state protection and misinterpretation of IRPA
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants provided evidence of past trauma; RPD found efforts to seek state protection insufficient
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Evidence of past trauma, police response, attempts to access state protection
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Perceived lack of diligence in seeking state protection in Mexico
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to reasonably seek state protection before fleeing
Crimes.Application_Error: Insufficient evidence of inability to access state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Not explicitly stated; emphasis on lack of reporting and engagement with authorities
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Need to demonstrate persecution or inability to access state protection under IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Claimants’ failure to report incidents and engage with police
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for evidence assessment, correctness for legal interpretation and bias
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged misrepresentation in border documentation or claim process

Crimes.Victim_Status: Ms. Garcia Rivadeneyra, adult female survivor
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Multiple incidents including sexual assault and robbery
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: None identified by RPD; claimant failed to report all incidents
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Not applicable to victim; no information on perpetrator criminal history
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – violent personal crime involving sexual assault
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: RPD concluded risk could be mitigated through state protection
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Non-state actor violence with alleged lack of effective state response
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Possibly gender-targeted, but not formally established
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Deemed insufficient due to lack of reporting and follow-up with authorities
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, medical or psychological records possibly included
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: RPD found claimant credible but actions inconsistent with claimed fear
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible but failed to take reasonable steps to access protection
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: N/A – no criminal prosecution in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA sections 96 and 97 regarding refugee status and need for protection

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Threats combined with prior sexual assault and robbery
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: No formal mitigation; threats not reported consistently
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – direct threats to life and safety
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: RPD assessed that state protection was available and adequate
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Possibly individualized based on prior attacks
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient to prove inability to access state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence of threats
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible but undermined by lack of engagement with authorities
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Found credible but not diligent in seeking protection

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Occurred alongside robbery, sexual assault, and threats
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: No evidence of state involvement; mixed evidence on police responsiveness
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: RPD found risks manageable through state protection mechanisms
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Non-state actor perpetration with alleged systemic corruption
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient to establish inability to access protection
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, possibly corroborative documents
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Consistent but lacking in procedural diligence

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged procedural unfairness and bias in RPD proceedings
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD properly assessed state protection and potential bias
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA and principles of procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: RPD considered applicant's claims of ineffective police response
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate inadequate state protection and bias
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Claims of misconduct not substantiated with sufficient evidence
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Bias allegations reviewed on correctness; other findings on reasonableness
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Correctness for bias, reasonableness for factual determinations
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged police ineffectiveness and procedural bias
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law standards applied to RPD decisions
Crimes.Defendant_Response: RPD maintained adequacy of state protection and absence of bias
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimonial, documentary, country condition evidence
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Overturn RPD decision and remit for re-hearing
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA and Charter-related procedural fairness rights

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Incidents occurred in conjunction with sexual assault and threats
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: No use of weapons specifically mentioned; no injuries detailed
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – violent property crime involving physical confrontation
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: RPD determined risk could be mitigated through state intervention
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient due to lack of reporting and follow-up
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, possible medical or police records
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible but actions inconsistent with claimed fear
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Found truthful but not proactive in seeking help

Violation_Type: Failure to consider compelling reasons exception
Legal_Provision_Violated: Paragraph 108(1)(e) and Subsection 108(4), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Application_Facts: Mr. Decka claimed persecution in Albania due to political opinion; Board found no current well-founded fear or need for protection due to changed country conditions; no explicit finding of past persecution
Procedural_Issue: Alleged failure by the Refugee Protection Division to consider the 'compelling reasons' exception under subsection 108(4) when grounds for protection ceased to exist
Evidence_Used: Country condition reports indicating changes in Albania
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of explicit finding on past persecution
Decision_Outcome: No error found in Board’s decision
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of the negative refugee determination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of paragraphs 108(1)(e) and 108(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Decision_Rationale: The Board had no obligation to consider compelling reasons under subsection 108(4) because it did not find past persecution; the cessation of protection grounds was justified based on changed country conditions

Legal_Provision_Violated: s. 18.1(4)(d) of the Federal Court Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to persecution in Mexico; Refugee Division found internal flight alternative to be reasonable; evidence about police presence in Toluca and psychological impact was not addressed
Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider critical evidence; lack of proper assessment of relocation expectation
Evidence_Used: Applicant's evidence regarding police vehicles in Toluca, psychological impact of persecution
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Refugee Division did not address key evidence on safety concerns outside Mexico City
Decision_Outcome: Original decision rejected claim based on internal flight alternative
Outcome: Decision set aside; case remitted for reconsideration by a new panel
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review; reassessment of refugee claim
Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious possibility of persecution; reasonableness of internal flight alternative
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness; correctness for questions of law
Decision_Rationale: It was unreasonable to expect relocation without assessing risks in Toluca; failure to consider evidence rendered decision perversely
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa and made multiple unsuccessful immigration applications
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review conducted under reasonableness standard
Evidence_Used: Personal Information Form (PIF)
Mother's letter
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly questioned, but evidence deemed insufficient
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Lack of credible and sufficient evidence to establish risk upon removal

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work without authorization under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant had failed refugee claims and was under deportation order
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to unauthorized work and status violations
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review assessed procedural fairness and evidence sufficiency
Evidence_Used: Personal Information Form (PIF)
Mother's letter
Timing of application
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Limited personal evidence; lack of corroboration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credibility not directly challenged, but evidence considered insufficient
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No credible threat established; delays in filing undermined claim strength

Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Alleged insufficient consideration of submitted evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: PIF and mother's letter were considered
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: Cooperation with U.S. authorities in drug case
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Criminal inadmissibility due to involvement in drug conspiracy
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Fear of reprisals in Dominican Republic due to cooperation with U.S. law enforcement
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Insufficient evidence of personal risk; no procedural unfairness found

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed forced marriage and domestic violence as basis for asylum
Procedural_Issue: RAD's standard of review on RPD's credibility assessment
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Credibility issues in applicant's testimony
Credibility_Assessment: RPD rejected claim due to credibility concerns; RAD upheld the finding
Decision_Outcome: RAD upheld RPD's negative credibility assessment
Outcome: Federal Court dismissed judicial review application
Legal_Standard_Applied: RAD must conduct independent analysis unless RPD's credibility finding is reasonable
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard applied by RAD to RPD's credibility finding
Decision_Rationale: RAD's analysis was sufficient and within acceptable legal bounds
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Refugee Appeal Division (RAD), Federal Court

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s.96
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed FARC threats due to refusal of vacuna tax
Procedural_Issue: PRRA officer dismissed evidence as self-serving and uncorroborated
Federal Court reviewed under reasonableness standard
Evidence_Used: Applicant's claim of FARC threats
New evidence cited in judicial review
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Evidence deemed self-serving and uncorroborated
Credibility_Assessment: Officer found applicant's evidence lacked credibility
Decision_Outcome: PRRA application dismissed
Legal_Standard_Applied: Assessment of subjective and objective risks of persecution
Decision_Rationale: No reviewable error; decision was reasonable and defensible
No breach of fairness
State protection finding upheld

Application_Facts: Harry was absent from Canada for most of the required period, pursuing studies abroad and making only sporadic visits; he owned property in Canada but did not reside there sufficiently
Residency_Compliance: No – less than three years of physical presence in Canada within the four years preceding application
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from Citizenship Judge to Federal Court Trial Division
Evidence_Used: Records of travel and residence abroad, property ownership documents, application records
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of physical residence in Canada during required period
Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and overturning of citizenship denial
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of 'residence' under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: Residency requires more than property ownership; physical presence in Canada for at least three of the past four years is mandatory and not satisfied

Application_Facts: Applicant was absent from Canada for 171 days during the four-year period preceding the application, falling short of the required 1,095 days of physical residency
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet 1,095-day physical presence requirement
Procedural_Issue: Inadequate reasons provided by Citizenship Judge; failure to explain calculations or consider all evidence
Evidence_Used: ICES reports
OHIP reports
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Judge did not adequately address or analyze submitted evidence including ICES and OHIP records
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application denied
Remedy_Sought: New hearing before a different Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical residence requirement of 1,095 days in four years
Decision_Rationale: Decision found unreasonable due to lack of justification, transparency, and intelligibility in the Judge's reasoning

Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 108(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed past domestic abuse and fear of persecution by Boko Haram; Board found no well-founded fear of persecution
Procedural_Issue: Alleged failure to properly apply Gender Guidelines in assessment
Evidence_Used: Threats from Boko Haram, history of domestic abuse
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence to establish well-founded fear of persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; Board's assessment upheld
Decision_Outcome: Refugee status denied
Remedy_Sought: Certification of a question of law or mixed fact and law
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution
Decision_Rationale: Board's decision was justified, transparent, and intelligible; no reviewable error found
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to meet residency requirements for citizenship
Crimes.Application_Facts: Respondents spent less than 50% of their time in Canada due to business-related absences; physical presence fell short of required 1,095 days within four years
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet minimum 3-year physical presence requirement
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge failed to properly apply the Koo test
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Business success and international travel records
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of meaningful ties to Canada under Koo criteria
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of application by a different Citizenship Judge
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Koo test for assessing residency in absence of full physical presence
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Judge improperly substituted business justifications for actual physical attachment to Canada; ignored key Koo factors

Crimes.Violation_Type: False or misleading representation regarding residency
Crimes.Application_Facts: Respondents spent less than 50% of time in Canada; significant absences for business; only two of six Koo factors favored residency claim
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Applications approved despite clear failure to meet residency obligations, implying inaccurate assessment of facts
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Improper application of Koo test by Citizenship Judge
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Travel history, business activities abroad, limited connections to Canada
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of documentation demonstrating strong residential ties to Canada
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reassessment by a new Citizenship Judge
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Koo test for qualitative assessment of residency
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Judge unreasonably prioritized business needs over statutory residency requirements and established Koo criteria

Application_Facts: Applicant is a Christian convert facing potential risk upon return to Bahrain
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide sufficient reasons for decision
Inadequate explanation of adverse findings
Evidence_Used: Assessment of conditions for Christian converts in Bahrain
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of detailed reasoning linking evidence to conclusion
Insufficient analysis of risks to converts
Decision_Outcome: Denial of humanitarian and compassionate application
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration by a different immigration officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness
Decision_Rationale: Officer failed to meaningfully assess risk and provide adequate reasons

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk upon return to Algeria due to sexual orientation and perceived Jewish identity; previous asylum claims denied
Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimant seeking PRRA and H&C relief
Residency_Compliance: Subject to deportation; residency not established or maintained
Procedural_Issue: Lack of procedural fairness
Failure to provide oral hearing despite credibility concerns
Evidence_Used: Affidavits, personal testimony, documentary evidence related to sexual orientation and religious perception
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer required more corroborative evidence than reasonably necessary
Some evidence was ignored
Credibility_Assessment: Implicit adverse credibility findings made without oral hearing
Decision_Outcome: PRRA and H&C applications refused
Relief_Sought: Positive determination on PRRA and H&C applications
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard for PRRA/H&C decisions
Correctness for procedural fairness and legal questions
Decision_Rationale: Unreasonable demand for corroboration
Breach of procedural fairness
Inadequate consideration of evidence

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Violation of procedural fairness and reasonableness of decision
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants were aware of their immigration history and prior cautions
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Past reports of unauthorized work, immigration history
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section requiring proof of intent to leave Canada at end of authorized stay
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Officer relied on undisclosed adverse information
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicants' knowledge of immigration history and previous warnings
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review under s. 72(1) of the Act
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged failure to disclose adverse reports
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None found; Officer considered available evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness requires notice of adverse information
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of compliance mixed with past violations

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of work permit and visitor record refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness and reasonableness in refusal based on unauthorized work
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Ronner had history of unauthorized work; Ms. Ronner allegedly assisted unpaid
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Reports of prior unauthorized work, business involvement
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Officer used undisclosed reports to justify refusal
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Prior work violations and risk of non-compliance
Crimes.Application_Error: Lack of explicit disclosure of all adverse reports
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonable opportunity to respond to adverse information
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None found; context supported reasonable conclusions
Crimes.Application_Factor: Long presence in Canada and family ties

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to leave Canada by end of authorized stay
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Requirement to depart at end of temporary status
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants sought extensions but had history of non-compliance
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Implied through continued stay despite risks
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of Officer to assess compliance
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Immigration history, prior reports of unauthorized work
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Doubts about intent to leave Canada
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Risk of continued non-compliance and past violations

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of extension refusal based on work violations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Use of undisclosed reports and procedural fairness
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Ronner aware of past concerns despite claims of unawareness
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Historical reports from 1990 and 1992 on unauthorized work
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Prohibition on foreign nationals working without permit
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Officer relied on undisclosed adverse information
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Pattern of non-compliance and credibility concerns
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to explicitly disclose all adverse reports
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Opportunity to respond to negative findings
Crimes.Application_Factor: Length of stay and integration in Canada

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed refugee status based on perceived political persecution; Member dismissed country conditions due to disbelief in subjective fear; delay in leaving Italy was reasonable given Sida's need to confirm suspicions and organize his family.
Procedural_Issue: Delay in leaving Italy assessed as reasonable; error in linking credibility to objective risk assessment
Evidence_Used: Country conditions, subjective fear, timing of departure from Italy
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to properly consider country conditions despite relevance to objective risk
Credibility_Assessment: Subjective fear disbelieved, but improper to dismiss country conditions solely on this basis
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected by Immigration and Refugee Board
Outcome: Judicial review granted; Board’s decision quashed
Legal_Standard_Applied: Separate consideration of country conditions under Section 97
Standard_of_Review: Patent unreasonableness for factual findings; correctness for legal issues
Decision_Rationale: Member erred by rejecting country conditions due to disbelief in subjective fear; country conditions must be assessed independently for objective risk

Violation_Type: Failure to recognize personalized risk under IRPA
Application_Facts: Tomlinson was targeted due to his brother's actions against a gang, resulting in specific threats and attacks; the Board incorrectly classified the risk as generalized based on Jamaica's crime rates.
Procedural_Issue: Board's erroneous characterization of risk; case remanded for re-determination by a different panel
Evidence_Used: Threats and attacks linked to gang retaliation; brother's police work
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to properly assess individualized risk despite evidence of targeted violence
Decision_Outcome: Board's decision found unreasonable
Relief_Sought: Recognition of personalized risk and refugee protection
Remedy_Sought: Remand for re-determination by a different Board panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 97(1)(b)(ii) of IRPA – personalized risk not shared by the general population
Decision_Rationale: Tomlinson faced a specific, personal risk due to familial association with a police officer who acted against a gang, which is distinct from generalized violence in Jamaica.

Application_Facts: Applicants argue Phase II materials influenced Phase I findings; emails from Phase I may have been seen by the Commissioner
Procedural_Issue: Access to materials for judicial review
Procedural fairness
Bias claims
Evidence_Used: Phase I emails
Perreault-related materials
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence that Phase II materials were before the decision-maker during Phase I
Decision_Outcome: Phase II materials excluded
Phase I emails and Perreault-related materials ordered to be provided
Outcome: Partial grant of request for materials
Relief_Sought: Access to Commission materials from Phase II and emails from Phase I
Remedy_Sought: Disclosure of documents for judicial review purposes
Legal_Standard_Applied: Relevance under Rule 317
Documents must affect the court's decision and be before the decision-maker
Decision_Rationale: Only materials before the decision-maker or relevant to procedural fairness or bias are disclosable; no link established between Phase II materials and Phase I decisions

Crime_Name: Immigration-related offences under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Ms. Behrooznia provided new evidence of political involvement after her refugee hearing; Officer dismissed it without adequate consideration, conflating past and new activities.
Procedural_Issue: Failure to properly consider new evidence; lack of procedural fairness
Evidence_Used: New evidence of post-hearing political involvement
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer did not adequately assess credibility or materiality of new evidence
Credibility_Assessment: Officer questioned credibility but failed to provide reasoned analysis
Decision_Outcome: PRRA application rejected
Remedy_Sought: Remittal to a different PRRA Officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard under administrative law
Decision_Rationale: Decision was unreasonable due to inadequate consideration of new evidence

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness and procedural fairness of PRRA Officer's decision
Credibility_Assessment: Officer found some evidence insufficiently credible
Evidence_Type: Evidence related to risks based on religion, gender, and political involvement
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to religion, gender, and political opinion
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Use of fraudulent travel documents; sufficiency and novelty of evidence
Proceeding_Type: Pre-Removal Risk Assessment (PRRA) and subsequent judicial review
Application_Error: Failure to recognize new evidence on political involvement
Evidence_Ignored: New evidence of political involvement submitted post-refugee hearing
Application_Factor: Presence of fraudulent documents and claimed risk upon return
Decision_Outcome: PRRA application initially rejected
Document_Fraud: Applicant arrived in Canada using fraudulent travel documents

Application_Facts: Mr. MacDonnell denied allegations but provided no evidence. Multiple police reports indicated his involvement in drug activities.
Procedural_Issue: Transport Canada passed this information to him, and despite having the chance, he failed to refute it effectively.
Evidence_Used: Multiple police reports
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Mr. MacDonnell provided no evidence to refute the allegations.
Credibility_Assessment: Denials were not supported by evidence, leading to low credibility.
Decision_Outcome: Revocation was procedurally fair and met the required standard of proof.
Legal_Standard_Applied: Balance of probabilities
Decision_Rationale: The Minister reasonably believed Mr. MacDonnell may commit or assist in acts interfering with civil aviation based on credible police reports.

Dispute_Type: Security clearance revocation based on alleged criminal activity
Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Mr. MacDonnell was given opportunity to respond but failed to provide sufficient counter-evidence.
Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Police reports were disclosed to Mr. MacDonnell by Transport Canada.
Decision_Outcome: Revocation was procedurally fair and based on reasonable belief.
Review_Mechanism: Judicial review under the Aeronautics Act
Authority_Responsible: Advisory Body and Minister of Transport
Applicant_Criminal_Background: Allegations of drug use and trafficking
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Potential risk to civil aviation security
Risk_Nexus: Drug-related activities may indicate vulnerability to coercion or compromise in aviation security context
Decision_Maker: Advisory Body recommended revocation; Minister made final decision
Outcome: Security clearance revoked; judicial review dismissed with costs against Mr. MacDonnell.
Basis_for_Decision: Reasonable belief that individual may unlawfully interfere with civil aviation
Legal_Framework: Aeronautics Act and related security policies
Procedural_Fairness_Breach: None found – Mr. MacDonnell had opportunity to respond.

Dispute_Type: Administrative decision to revoke security clearance
Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness and burden of proof in revocation
Governing_Law: Aeronautics Act and associated security policies
Evidence_Assessment: Hearsay from law enforcement deemed sufficient under policy.
Decision_Outcome: Revocation upheld as procedurally fair and meeting burden of proof.
Burden_of_Proof: Balance of probabilities; Minister must reasonably believe individual may interfere with aviation.
Credibility_Factor: Mr. MacDonnell’s denials lacked supporting evidence.
Legal_Rule: Individual may commit or assist in acts interfering with civil aviation.
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged drug use and dealing raising security concerns.
Legal_Framework: Transport Canada Security Policy under Aeronautics Act
Outcome: Revocation upheld; costs awarded against Mr. MacDonnell.
Legal_Provision: Section of Aeronautics Act authorizing security clearance decisions

Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution risk in India and China, previously denied asylum in the USA, sought refugee protection in Canada
Claimant_Status: Stateless, claimed entitlement to Indian citizenship but not recognized by India, not considered a citizen of China
Procedural_Issue: RPD's decision contained contradictory findings on citizenship
Remanded for re-determination by a different panel
Jurisdictional_Issue: Interpretation of foreign law (Indian citizenship law) by RPD
Evidence_Used: Evidence that India does not recognize Tibetans as citizens
Lack of proof that China would interpret Indian law as granting citizenship
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence to support conclusion that Applicant was entitled to Indian citizenship
Decision_Outcome: RPD found Applicant not a citizen of China
Remedy_Sought: Re-determination of refugee status by a different RPD panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard in interpreting foreign law
Decision_Rationale: RPD's conclusion was unreasonable due to internal contradictions regarding citizenship status and lack of supporting evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility to Canada under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants involved in MV Sun Sea voyage; claimed they were refugees aiding navigation, not smugglers
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Entered Canada illegally without proper documents
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Board declined to address constitutional arguments due to lack of notice under Rule 47
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Involvement in organizing or facilitating irregular entry via MV Sun Sea
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider international definitions of smuggling requiring profit or clandestine intent
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Board found applicants inadmissible for people smuggling
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside, matter referred back for reconsideration
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of inadmissibility by the Board
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation aligned with international instruments under IRPA s 3(3)(f)
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for constitutional issues; correctness for statutory interpretation
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Board erred in interpreting 'people smuggling' and rejecting constitutional arguments without proper notice
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Interpretation of 'people smuggling' under IRPA and procedural fairness
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Constitutional arguments dismissed without adequate opportunity to present them
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: International definitions of smuggling not adequately considered
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Board deemed J.P. a smuggler based on role as navigator without legal documentation
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board
Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Alleged facilitation of illegal entry through navigation assistance on MV Sun Sea
Crimes.Mode_of_Entry: By boat (MV Sun Sea), irregular maritime arrival
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: No indication of prior criminal record; claimed humanitarian intent
Crimes.Evidence_Source: Board's assessment of applicants’ roles in the voyage
Crimes.Outcome: Board’s decision overturned; remanded for redetermination
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Unreasonable interpretation inconsistent with international law (requirement of profit or clandestine intent)
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA s 3(3)(f) requiring alignment with international instruments
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Correctness for statutory interpretation, reasonableness for constitutional issues
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to provide notice and opportunity to address constitutional challenges

Application_Facts: Appellant was physically present in Canada for only 232 days over a four-year period; maintained a home in Canada; paid taxes as a resident; promoted Canadian interests in Hong Kong; absences were due to business responsibilities in Hong Kong
Residency_Compliance: No, did not accumulate at least three years of residence in Canada within four years preceding application
Procedural_Issue: Appeal involved a trial de novo before the Federal Court
Evidence_Used: Physical presence records, ownership/maintenance of home in Canada, tax filings, promotion of Canadian interests, nature and purpose of absences
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient demonstration that connection to Canada was more substantial than to Hong Kong
Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed
Legal_Standard_Applied: Residence under Section 5(1)(c) requires both physical presence and intent to reside, with stronger ties to Canada than to another country
Decision_Rationale: Appellant's absences were not temporary; business responsibilities in Hong Kong outweighed his connections to Canada; residence requirement not satisfied despite some ties to Canada

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section of the Citizenship Act requiring 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada within four years prior to application
Application_Facts: Ms. Kettani applied for Canadian citizenship; Minister challenged her compliance with residency requirements
Residency_Compliance: Citizenship judge found that Ms. Kettani met the 1,095-day physical presence requirement
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review under section 22.1 of the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, supporting documents, answers to questions during hearing
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inconsistencies in evidence noted but resolved by credibility assessment
Credibility_Assessment: Citizenship judge found Ms. Kettani credible despite some inconsistencies
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship judge approved application
Outcome: Court dismissed judicial review; decision upheld
Relief_Sought: Minister sought to set aside the citizenship judge’s decision
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the citizenship judge’s decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical presence test under the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: The judge properly applied the law, assessed credibility, and made reasonable findings based on evidence
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship judge under the Citizenship Act

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of PRRA Officer's decision
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claim found not credible due to vague evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Anecdotal and uncorroborated claims about police involvement
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of torture by Georgian police official over unpaid debt
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of evidence linking individual to state actors
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide sufficient evidence supporting risk claim
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard with deference to officer expertise
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of false passport at entry

Crimes.Crime_Name: False documents for the purpose of gaining entry
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of PRRA Officer's assessment of risk claim
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim of persecution lacked evidentiary support
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Unsubstantiated allegations of threats from criminal with police links
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of harm due to use of false documents and alleged connections
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: No proof of state involvement or lack of protection
Crimes.Application_Error: Insufficient evidence to establish personal risk
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of fraudulent travel document upon entry
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Submission of false passport for entry into Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to make a refugee claim prior to removal order
Crimes.Violation_Type: Procedural non-compliance in refugee claim process
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA sections related to timely refugee claims
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant entered with false documents and delayed claiming refugee status
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Prior use of false passport affecting credibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to file refugee claim before removal order issued
Crimes.Evidence_Used: PRRA submission and background country information
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of concrete evidence on state inability to protect
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims deemed speculative and unverified
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal based on risk claims
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Georgia capable of providing protection; no nexus to state persecution

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether private debt dispute constitutes grounds for protection
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Vague and uncorroborated claims about police-linked creditor
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate personal risk and state complicity
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Lack of documentation or third-party verification
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Private disputes not equivalent to persecution without state involvement
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged threats from individual allegedly connected to police
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to insufficient evidence
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of debt, alleged ties to law enforcement, availability of state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Self-reported narrative without corroboration

Legal_Issue: Can the Minister rescind a 1998 decision to cease disability benefits based on new facts under subsection 84(2)?
Can retroactive payments extend beyond statutory limits?
Evidence_Assessment: Second application in 2004 with medical evidence
Decision_Outcome: Minister correctly refused to rescind 1998 decision or extend retroactive payments
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show grounds for rescission or entitlement to retroactive benefits
Credibility_Factor: Applicant did not appeal initial decision; delay in reapplication
Legal_Rule: Subsection 84(2) CPP allows rescission of decisions based on new facts
Section 42 CPP limits retroactive payments to 15 months prior to application
Res judicata bars collateral attack on final administrative decisions
Grounds_for_Claim: Request for reinstatement of benefits from 1998
Key_Evidence_Considered: Medical records indicating improved health in 1998
Defendant_Response: Minister refused rescission and extended retroactivity based on statutory limits and finality of prior decision
Remedy_Requested: Extension of retroactive payments beyond 15 months
Authority: Minister of Employment and Social Development

Dispute_Type: Visa denial based on medical inadmissibility of non-accompanying family member
Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of visa denial under IRPA and Regulations regarding medical inadmissibility and adoption genuineness
Governing_Law: IRPA s.42(a), Regulations s.23, Regulations s.4
Outcome: Decision found unreasonable; case remitted for redetermination
Credibility_Assessment: Adoption by aunt deemed not genuine
Evidence_Type: Medical records, custody arrangements, adoption documentation
Legal_Provision: IRPA s.42(a) – inadmissibility due to health grounds; Regulations s.23 – exemption for valid custody; Regulations s.4 – bad faith adoptions
Basis_of_Claim: Medical inadmissibility of non-accompanying child (Dong Jun)
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to consider applicability of s.23 and inadequate analysis of adoption legality
Application_Error: Failure to apply regulatory exemption under s.23; insufficient assessment of adoption
Evidence_Ignored: Potential validity of custody arrangement under s.23
Legal_Standard: Standard of reasonableness in administrative decision-making
Application_Factor: Non-accompanying disabled child excluded from application
Decision_Outcome: Overturned and remanded
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations

Credibility_Assessment: Supported by consistent reporting and corroborative circumstances

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, had criminal record, claimed threats in home country
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent Resident or applicant for PRRA
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Assessment of procedural fairness in PRRA decision
Evidence_Used: Criminal record
Claims of threats in Dominican Republic
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of risk upon return
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims not credible due to lack of supporting evidence
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, unless procedural fairness issue arises
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No credible risk of torture or cruel treatment found; insufficient evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility and sufficiency of evidence in PRRA claim
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's evidence lacked credibility
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Risk of harm upon return to Dominican Republic
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Insufficient personal evidence and credibility concerns
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide sufficient credible evidence

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: IRPA - Risk of torture or cruel treatment (s. 115)
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: Yes, including cooperation with U.S. authorities
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Claimed danger due to past cooperation with U.S. law enforcement
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Insufficient evidence of credible risk; delay in applying

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to demonstrate intent to leave Canada
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, SOR/2002-227
Crimes.Application_Facts: Nguyen, a Vietnamese citizen, had a nine-month absence from his Vietnamese business and expressed intent to stay in Canada with his children.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national applying for a work permit
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to prove compliance with temporary residency requirements
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review assessed reasonableness of visa officer's decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Applicant's ties to Vietnam, duration of absence from business, statements about family in Canada
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of strong evidence showing intent to return to Vietnam
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Nguyen's claim of intent to return was weakened by prolonged absence and desire to remain with children
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn refusal and grant work permit
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Proof of intention to leave Canada at the end of authorized stay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Tribunal reasonably concluded Nguyen did not prove he would leave Canada after his authorized stay

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer acted reasonably in refusing the work permit due to insufficient proof of intent to leave Canada
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, Regulation 200(1)(b)
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; work permit not issued
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Nguyen lacked strong ties to Vietnam and expressed desire to stay in Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Business ownership in Vietnam, duration of absence, familial connections in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Regulation 200(1)(b) – Requirement to prove intent to leave Canada
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Applicant failed to meet regulatory requirement to demonstrate intent to depart Canada
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Weak ties to home country and expressed intent to remain in Canada
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide sufficient evidence of intent to leave Canada
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Objective assessment of applicant’s intent based on ties to home country
Crimes.Application_Factor: Duration of absence from Vietnamese business and presence of children in Canada
Crimes.Authority: Canadian Visa Office, Immigration and Refugee Board

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of RPD's Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) analysis
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; case remanded for reconsideration
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution by Qaddafi regime supporters
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to assess IFA conditions for minor child
Application_Error: Failure to assess country conditions and impact on minor child
Legal_Standard: Two-prong IFA test: no serious possibility of persecution and reasonable relocation conditions
Decision_Outcome: RPD decision found unreasonable; remanded to different panel

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion of refugee claimant despite negative danger opinion
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can the Minister of Public Safety exclude a refugee claimant after a negative danger opinion by the Minister of Citizenship and Immigration?
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not applicable (decision based on legal interpretation, not credibility)
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Conviction record, asylum application documents
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention, IRPA sections 98, 101, 112
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Seriousness of the crime committed abroad
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Seriousness of the crime (murder conviction abroad)
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Federal Court, Immigration and Refugee Board
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Article 1F(b) exclusion under the Refugee Convention
Crimes.Application_Factor: Nature and seriousness of the foreign conviction
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border or immigration documents

Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Refugee claimant with prior foreign conviction
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Seriousness of the crime, foreign conviction for violent offense
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Rehabilitation and current dangerousness considered but deemed irrelevant
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Assessed as not requiring individualized evaluation due to crime seriousness
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Potential threat due to past violent crime
Crimes.Threat_Source: Individual with history of violent criminal conduct
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Foreign court conviction, immigration and refugee claim documents
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not challenged; conviction accepted as fact
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Not applicable (focus on exclusion, not sentencing)
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention, IRPA sections 98, 101, 112

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD's conclusion on the primary purpose of Gill's marriage was reasonable and whether the correct version of s. 4 was applied
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) Regulations, section 4
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Husband's history and credibility issues affected assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimony, documentary evidence, immigration history
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Marriage entered primarily for immigration benefits
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Amended s. 4 test (disjunctive: genuine or for immigration benefits)
Crimes.Application_Factor: Proceedings treated as de novo; amended regulation applied

Crimes.Crime_Name: Marriage Fraud under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD's conclusion on the primary purpose of Gill's marriage was reasonable and if the correct version of s. 4 was applied
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) Regulations, section 4
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Husband's history and credibility issues were central to determination
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimony, documentary evidence, immigration history
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Marriage entered primarily for immigration benefits despite being genuine
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Amended s. 4 test (disjunctive: genuine or for immigration benefits)
Crimes.Application_Factor: Proceedings treated as de novo; amended regulation applied

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the risks faced by Mr. Guifarro are personalized or generalized under IRPA s. 97(1)(b)(ii)
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 97(1)(b)(ii)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD found risk generalized, not personalized
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimony regarding gang threats and extortion
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of gang-related violence and extortion in Honduras
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Risk perceived as generalized among those believed to have money
Crimes.Application_Factor: Perceived wealth leading to extortion threats
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Claim rejected; refugee status not granted

Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Gang's history of extortion and violence
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Threats and extortion based on perceived wealth
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal testimony and country condition evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Accepted but deemed indicative of generalized risk
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Consistent but not sufficient to prove personalization

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Refusal to comply with extortion demands
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal account of assault
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Consistent with generalized threat pattern

Crimes.Evidence_Type: Direct personal experience
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Aligned with broader societal issue

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Ongoing threats following refusal to pay
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Pervasive in regions controlled by gangs
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal narrative and contextual evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Accepted as true but not individually distinctive

Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Diallo would face unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship if required to apply for permanent residence from Guinea
Procedural_Stage: Judicial Review of H&C Application Decision
Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistencies in application, lack of personalized risk evidence, establishment in Canada
Decision_Outcome: H&C application denied; judicial review dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant must prove unusual hardship beyond normal immigration requirements
Credibility_Factor: Inconsistencies in Mr. Diallo's application affected credibility
Legal_Rule: Applicant must demonstrate exceptional circumstances causing unusual hardship not anticipated by the Immigration Act
Grounds_for_Claim: Hardship due to conditions in Guinea and establishment in Canada
Outcome_on_Merits: No exceptional hardship found; officer's decision upheld
Key_Evidence_Considered: Conditions in Guinea, applicant's ties to Canada, inconsistencies in testimony
Legal_Framework: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds under IRPA
Defendant_Response: Officer concluded no exceptional hardship based on lack of evidence
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, personal claims, country condition reports
Remedy_Requested: Permanent residence in Canada on H&C grounds
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Mr. Diallo must apply for permanent residence from Guinea
Legal_Provision: Section 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Authority: Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC), Federal Court

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Chen met the residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Chen's evidence was found incomplete and misleading
Evidence_Type: Credit card statements showing Canadian charges while claiming to be abroad
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to prove physical presence in Canada for at least 1,095 days
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Conflicting and insufficient evidence regarding residency
Crimes.Application_Error: Inaccurate or inconsistent reporting of residency
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to factual findings
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Applicant must demonstrate physical presence in Canada for 1,095 days
Crimes.Application_Factor: Reliability and consistency of submitted evidence
Crimes.Authority: Citizenship judge under the Citizenship Act

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Chen provided sufficient evidence to meet the residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Chen's evidence was inconsistent, incomplete, and deemed misleading
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to provide credible and consistent evidence of physical presence in Canada
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Discrepancies in documentation and lack of reliable proof
Crimes.Application_Error: Submission of conflicting and unreliable information
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to evaluation of evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Applicant must prove physical presence in Canada for 1,095 days with credible evidence
Crimes.Application_Factor: Consistency and credibility of evidence presented
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed; Mr. Chen failed to prove residency requirements
Crimes.Authority: Citizenship judge under the Citizenship Act

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of immigration inadmissibility decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer's decision to deny permanent residence based on association with ELF was legally sound
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), paragraph 34(1)(f)
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision set aside for redetermination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer's reasoning found flawed due to inadequate definition of terrorism
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Internet-sourced definition of terrorism, association evidence
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to properly define 'terrorism' and overreach on family inadmissibility
Crimes.Application_Error: Improper assumption of inadmissibility based on familial association
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Legal interpretation of terrorist or subversive activity under IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Lack of evidence linking family members directly to ELF activities
Crimes.Application_Factor: Association with organization alleged to engage in terrorism
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision overturned, case remanded for redetermination

Crimes.Crime_Name: Section 87 non-disclosure application delays and over-assertion of secrecy
Crimes.Violation_Type: Procedural delay and excessive secrecy claims
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 87 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 87
Crimes.Application_Facts: Delayed section 87 application and rescheduling of proceedings
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Eritrean refugees applying for permanent residence
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Delay in filing section 87 application and overbroad secrecy assertions by CSIS
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of transparency due to excessive secrecy
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Concerns about balance between national security and fairness
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Procedural flaws identified; recommendations for improvement
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted on other grounds; case remanded
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Fair and timely processing of permanent residence application
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Fairness and timeliness in non-disclosure processes
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Delays and over-assertion of secrecy undermined procedural fairness

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility due to association with terrorist or subversive activities
Crimes.National_Security_Element: Alleged membership in a terrorist organization (ELF)
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential risk from association with group engaging in subversive activities
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Based on past affiliation without individualized risk analysis
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Terrorist or subversive activities as defined under IRPA
Crimes.Leadership_Role: No indication of leadership role specified
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Officer relied on internet search, not authoritative sources
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Internet-based definition, organizational records
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer's interpretation deemed unreasonable
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Lack of proper legal foundation for defining terrorism
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Balance of probabilities in administrative immigration context
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Initial denial of permanent residence; later set aside for redetermination

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility to Canada under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Memon was a member of MQM-A from 1994 to 1999, an organization found to engage in terrorism based on credible evidence including reports from Amnesty International.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent resident or applicant for admission
Evidence_Used: Amnesty International reports
Documentary evidence on MQM-A's activities including torture chambers and kidnappings
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: The IAD found the evidence credible and compelling; court found assessment reasonable.
Crimes.Outcome: Mr. Memon remains inadmissible to Canada
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of IAD's inadmissibility determination
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: The IAD reasonably concluded that MQM-A engaged in terrorism against civilians and non-combatants, and Mr. Memon’s membership triggered inadmissibility under IRPA.

Crimes.Crime_Name: Being a member of an organization that there are reasonable grounds to believe engages, has engaged or will engage in acts of terrorism
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat due to association with a terrorist organization
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: MQM-A engaged in terrorism including torture and kidnapping
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Membership in an organization involved in violent and terroristic acts
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: High – based on credible documentary sources including international human rights reports
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Distinction between MQM factions and whether membership implies support for terrorism
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: The court accepted the IAD's credibility assessment of the evidence linking MQM-A to terrorism.
Credibility_Factors: Consistency of reporting across time and sources
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 34(1)(f)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Interpretation of membership and organizational linkage to terrorism
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Inadmissibility to Canada and deportation order

Crime_Name: Predatory Pricing and Unlawful Interference with Economic Interests
Legal_Issue: Whether the defendants' free online exam guides constituted predatory pricing or unlawful interference with the plaintiff's economic interests
Evidence_Assessment: No proof of intent to harm competition or actual causation of plaintiff's losses; multiple factors contributed to sales decline
Decision_Outcome: Action dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On the plaintiff to prove predatory pricing or unlawful interference
Credibility_Factor: Plaintiff failed to establish causal link between free guides and financial loss
Legal_Rule: Predatory pricing involves selling at unreasonably low prices to eliminate competitors; unlawful interference requires unlawful means, intent to injure, and actual injury
Grounds_for_Claim: Defendants offering free online exams harmed plaintiff's business and violated the Competition Act
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed on merits due to lack of evidence
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of free online exam guides as marketing tools, market conditions, plaintiff's declining sales data
Legal_Framework: Competition law, tort of unlawful interference with economic interests
Defendant_Response: Free guides were promotional tools, not intended to harm competition
Remedy_Requested: Legal action for violation of Competition Act, likely damages or injunction
Legal_Provision: Sections of the Competition Act relating to predatory pricing; common law on economic torts
